title.narrative: Enhancing Resilience among South Sudanese Refugees and Host Community Members in Yumbe District through an Integrated Protection, WaSH and Livelihoods Response

description.narrative: The International Rescue Committee (IRC) will provide protection services, including specifically targeting individuals most at risk with a GBV prevention response and PSN (persons with specific needs) assistance. Norwegian Refugee Council (NRC) and Action Against Hunger will increase access to clean water at the household and institutional levels while promoting improved hygiene and sanitation practices amongst the community. The IRC and Action Against Hunger will target PSNs, youth and host community businesses in an integrated agricultural and non-agricultural livelihoods intervention that includes cash transfers. The multi-sector approach aims to provide linkages to durable solutions and promote peaceful coexistence between the refugee and host community.

The action seeks to address critical life-saving needs among the refugee population and surrounding host community in and around Bidibidi settlement. Refugees in Bidibidi have numerous and evolving protection needs, experiencing continued physical insecurity where they live in continued fear of tribal violence. Competition over natural resources such as water and wood has led to increased tensions between refugees and host communities across the settlement: threats predominantly affecting women as the collectors of these resources. Women are disproportionately affected by conflict and displacement, experiencing high rates of gender-based violence in South Sudan, in transit, and within refugee settlements. WaSH needs are paramount as a result of low household latrine coverage and a dependence on communal latrines, which instigate disease outbreak. Currently, refugees rely mainly on general food distribution and non-food item support to ensure their basic needs are met. Interventions are needed to shift from provision of humanitarian aid to sustainable enterprise development of refugees.
